abstracts.cdata!:
The project was satisfactory, with a
            likely sustainability, and substantial institutional
            development impacts. Lessons learned convey the following.
            Efforts to install performance contracts between government
            agencies which are intended to bring about changes,
            particularly behavioral, need to include provisions for
            sufficiently attractive incentives, to overcome resistance
            to change, and to generate support. As well, performance
            contracts need to be based on realistic, and clearly,
            defined assumptions, regarding how the expected performance
            changes would be judged - and what would occur if these are
            not accomplished. To this end, the staff of institutions
            targeted for reform should be informed on the goals, and
            methods to be developed, and used, to help ensure
            consistency, and common understandings of future
            responsibilities. Furthermore, plans for comprehensive
            institutional reforms should be carefully sequenced,
            complemented by provisions for broader approaches, when
            capacity, and readiness indicators so reveal. The project
            experience thus shows that, implementation of the new
            financial management system was enhanced by the application
            of a comprehensive, governing concept: the adoption of a
            rule-based system, accompanied by regulatory procedures on
            sub-systems, and supported by modern information technology.
            It is emphasized though, that future institutional reform
            projects be coordinated, to minimize inconsistencies, and
            conflicting provisions.

18157437.trustfund:
TF022477-PHRD-ECONOMIC RECOVERY CREDIT
            2/BANK EX.,TF022481-PHRD-SECOND ECONOMIC RECOVERY CREDIT,TF029370-PHRD -PUBLIC POLICY &
            ADMINISTRATIVE REFORM,TF039697-NICARAGUA - INSTITUTIONAL

            MANAGEMENT OF PUBLIC SECTOR MODERNIZATION
18157437.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Public sector governance

abstracts.cdata!:
The goal of the reform in Nicaragua is a
            public sector which is "small, strong, efficient...and
            [which] acts as a facilitator to the private sector."
            Successful implementation of a comprehensive, coherent, and
            well-targeted public sector modernization program would
            represent an important advance in Nicaragua's ongoing
            structural adjustment effort. The Institutional Development
            Project will be a major source of support for the reform
            effort. Its objectives will be improvement in service
            delivery by those institutions restructured under the
            program and increases in public savings attributable to the
            program. The project will be composed of the following
            components: 1) institutional restructuring; 2) civil service
            reform; 3) integrated financial management; 4) information
            technology; and 5) reform management.
